Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 19-year-old man in a 3-month relationship with a woman experiences frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers. He lives in a conservative community and does not know any openly gay men. Two days ago, he joined a local group considered by many organizations to be a hate group. Together with the other members, he attacked a gay couple on their way home from dinner. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is he demonstrating?
(A) Sublimation (B) Reaction formation (C) Intellectualization (D) Projection
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 19-year-old man in a 3-month relationship with a woman experiences frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers. He lives in a conservative community and does not know any openly gay men. Two days ago, he joined a local group considered by many organizations to be a hate group. Together with the other members, he attacked a gay couple on their way home from dinner. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is he demonstrating?
options: (A) Sublimation (B) Reaction formation (C) Intellectualization (D) Projection
outputs:
The patient has been experiencing frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers. He lives in a conservative community and does not know any openly gay men. He has joined a local group considered by many organizations to be a hate group. Together with the other members, he attacked a gay couple on their way home from dinner. He is experiencing a conflict between his sexual desires and his beliefs. He is trying to suppress his desires by attacking the gay couple. This is an example of reaction formation. The answer is (B).

Q: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after a fall from a bicycle. He is crying and holding his left arm. He has a depressed skull fracture. His Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is 13. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform a CT scan of the head (B) Perform a CT scan of the spine (C) Administer intravenous mannitol (D) Administer intravenous dexamethasone
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a depressed skull fracture and a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 13. The patient's symptoms indicate that he may have a brain injury. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform a CT scan of the head to evaluate the extent of the injury. The answer is (A).

Q: A 45-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents for follow-up. She has been compliant with her medications and diet. Her blood pressure today is 124/76 mm Hg, and her hemoglobin A1c is 8.1%. She has been experiencing worsening left lower extremity pain for the past 2 months. The pain is described as aching and is aggravated by walking. She has been using over-the-counter acetaminophen and ibuprofen without relief. Physical examination shows mild tenderness to palpation over the left tibia, and the patient limps. The patient's medications include metformin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Order an urgent MRI of the left lower extremity (B) Order an urgent CT scan of the left lower extremity (C) Initiate alendronate therapy (D) Initiate zoledronic acid therapy
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has worsening left lower extremity pain that is aggravated by walking. The patient's medications include metformin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a possible musculoskeletal problem. The most appropriate next step in management is to order an urgent MRI of the left lower extremity to evaluate for a possible stress fracture or other musculoskeletal abnormality. The answer is (A).

Q: A 35-year-old woman with a history of migraines and a 2-day history of a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting presents to the emergency department. She has tried over-the-counter medications without relief. Her blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, and her pulse is 90/min. Physical examination shows a mild occipital headache with no other focal neurological signs. Complete blood cell count, electrolyte panel, and urinalysis are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer IV metoclopramide (B) Administer IV sumatriptan (C) Administer IV hydromorphone (D) Administer IV ondansetron
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of migraines and is currently experiencing a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a possible migraine attack. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer IV sumatriptan, a medication commonly used to treat migraines. The answer is (B).

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 66-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider with several days of left flank pain radiating to the abdomen and groin. The patient states that she has noticed a pink tinge to her urine as well. Of note, she has not had any fevers, but endorses several months of fatigue and constipation. The patient was previously healthy except for mild untreated hypertension. On exam, her temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure is 130/84 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 12/min. On further workup, the patient is found to have calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis with hypercalciuria. Blood studies demonstrate increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) and hypercalcemia. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
(A) Primary hyperparathyroidism (B) Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism (C) Secondary hyperparathyroidism (D) Tertiary hyperparathyroidism
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 66-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider with several days of left flank pain radiating to the abdomen and groin. The patient states that she has noticed a pink tinge to her urine as well. Of note, she has not had any fevers, but endorses several months of fatigue and constipation. The patient was previously healthy except for mild untreated hypertension. On exam, her temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure is 130/84 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 12/min. On further workup, the patient is found to have calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis with hypercalciuria. Blood studies demonstrate increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) and hypercalcemia. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
options: (A) Primary hyperparathyroidism (B) Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism (C) Secondary hyperparathyroidism (D) Tertiary hyperparathyroidism
outputs:
The patient presents with left flank pain radiating to the abdomen and groin, pink tinge to her urine, fatigue, and constipation. On exam, her temperature is 98.6°F (37.0°C), blood pressure is 130/84 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 12/min. On further workup, the patient is found to have calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis with hypercalciuria. Blood studies demonstrate increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) and hypercalcemia. The most likely cause is secondary hyperparathyroidism. Secondary hyperparathyroidism occurs when there is a chronic increase in the set point for calcium, such as in chronic kidney disease, leading to increased PTH secretion. The answer is (C).

Q: A 46-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of severe headache, fever, and confusion. He is awake but unable to speak and is noted to have a left-sided hemiparesis. He has a history of hypertension and smoking. On exam, his blood pressure is 220/110 mm Hg, pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 24/min. The patient is afebrile. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Ischemic stroke (B) Intracerebral hemorrhage (C) Subarachnoid hemorrhage (D) Meningitis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient presents with a 2-day history of severe headache, fever, and confusion. He is awake but unable to speak and is noted to have a left-sided hemiparesis. He has a history of hypertension and smoking. On exam, his blood pressure is 220/110 mm Hg, pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 24/min. The patient is afebrile. The most likely diagnosis is ischemic stroke. Ischemic stroke is a sudden reduction in blood flow to an area of the brain, leading to cell death. This can cause symptoms such as headache, fever, confusion, and hemiparesis. The patient's history of hypertension and smoking increases his risk of ischemic stroke. The answer is (A).

Q: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of sudden hearing loss in her right ear, accompanied by a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. She has no history of ear problems or previous illness. On examination, her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Otoscopy shows a Weber Class III/IV tympanic membrane perforation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer antibiotics and observe (B) Refer to otolaryngology for surgical repair (C) Perform mastoidectomy (D) Administer steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient presents with sudden hearing loss in her right ear, accompanied by a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. She has no history of ear problems or previous illness. On examination, her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Otoscopy shows a Weber Class III/IV tympanic membrane perforation. The most appropriate next step in management would be to refer the patient to otolaryngology for surgical repair. This is because the patient has a perforated eardrum, which can cause hearing loss and is usually treated with surgical repair. The answer is (B).

Q: A 23-year-old woman presents to her psychiatrist concerned about her mood. She has felt tired and unwilling to engage in any activities lately. She states that her limbs feel heavy all the time and that completing any activity takes tremendous effort. She no longer finds any happiness in activities that she previously enjoyed. She also states that she really struggles to sleep and at times can't sleep for several days. The patient is started on appropriate first-line therapy and sent home. She returns 1 week later stating that her symptoms have not improved. She is requesting help as her performance at work and school is suffering. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
(A) Add lithium to treatment regimen (B) Change treatment to lithium (C) Continue current therapy (D) Electroconvulsive therapy
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 23-year-old woman presents to her psychiatrist concerned about her mood. She has felt tired and unwilling to engage in any activities lately. She states that her limbs feel heavy all the time and that completing any activity takes tremendous effort. She no longer finds any happiness in activities that she previously enjoyed. She also states that she really struggles to sleep and at times can't sleep for several days. The patient is started on appropriate first-line therapy and sent home. She returns 1 week later stating that her symptoms have not improved. She is requesting help as her performance at work and school is suffering. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
options: (A) Add lithium to treatment regimen (B) Change treatment to lithium (C) Continue current therapy (D) Electroconvulsive therapy
outputs:
The patient has symptoms of depression. She has low energy, feels tired, and has a lack of interest in activities she used to enjoy. She also has difficulty sleeping. The patient has been started on appropriate first-line therapy. However, she has not improved after 1 week. The patient is requesting help as her symptoms are affecting her performance at work and school. The patient's symptoms are severe and are affecting her daily life. The best next step in management would be to add lithium to her treatment regimen. Lithium is a mood stabilizer that is commonly used to treat bipolar disorder. It can help to improve mood, increase energy, and improve sleep. The answer is (A).

Q: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He takes no medications and has no allergies. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a right hemiparesis and dysarthria. There is no evidence of trauma. Complete blood cell count shows WBC 12,000/mm3, hemoglobin 14.2 g/dL, hematocrit 42%, platelet count 250,000/mm3, and mean corpuscular volume 84 μm3. Electrolyte panel shows sodium 140 mEq/L, potassium 4.0 mEq/L, chloride 102 mEq/L, and bicarbonate 24 mEq/L. Urinalysis shows 2+ protein, 1+ blood, and 1+ casts. The patient's creatinine is 1.5 mg/dL. An ECG shows a prolonged QTc interval. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer furosemide (B) Administer lithium (C) Administer sodium thiosulfate (D) Administer hydrochlorothiazide
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. He has a right hemiparesis and dysarthria. The patient's blood work shows a WBC count of 12,000/mm3, hemoglobin of 14.2 g/dL, hematocrit of 42%, platelet count of 250,000/mm3, and mean corpuscular volume of 84 μm3. His electrolyte panel shows sodium of 140 mEq/L, potassium of 4.0 mEq/L, chloride of 102 mEq/L, and bicarbonate of 24 mEq/L. Urinalysis shows 2+ protein, 1+ blood, and 1+ casts. The patient's creatinine is 1.5 mg/dL. An ECG shows a prolonged QTc interval. The patient's symptoms are consistent with a stroke. The patient's lab work shows evidence of kidney damage. The patient's ECG shows a prolonged QTc interval, which is a sign of a potentially life-threatening arrhythmia. The best next step in management would be to administer furosemide. Furosemide is a diuretic that is used to treat edema. It will help to reduce the patient's blood pressure and improve renal function. The answer is (A).

Q: A 42-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-day history of worsening left knee pain. She describes the pain as sharp and localized to the medial aspect of the knee. She has no history of knee trauma or previous knee surgery. She has tried over-the-counter analgesics without relief. She has no other significant medical history. Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 16-year-old patient presents to the physician’s office with an absence of menstruations. Her last period was 6 months ago. Since almost a year and a half ago, she intentionally restricted her diet at the expense of carbohydrates, exercised intensively, and lost 18.0 kg (39.7 lb). She had her menarche at the age of 12 and menstruated normally until last year. She is not sexually active. On physical examination, the vital signs include blood pressure 100/60 mm Hg, heart rate 55/min, respiratory rate 12/min, and temperature 35.9°C (96.6°F). Her weight is 55.0 kg (121.3 lb), and her height is 166 cm (5 ft 5 in). Physical examination reveals the good development of muscles and decreased adiposity. A bone scan shows decreased calcium mineral deposits. Which statement about this patient’s condition is correct?
(A) This patient has insulin resistance (B) Decreased adiposity contributes to hypoestrogenemia in this patient (C) The patient is likely to have decreased blood estrogen concentration due to increased liver metabolism (D) The patient should be checked for hyperthyroidism because such extensive lipolysis is likely to result from thyroid hyperfunction
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 16-year-old patient presents to the physician’s office with an absence of menstruations. Her last period was 6 months ago. Since almost a year and a half ago, she intentionally restricted her diet at the expense of carbohydrates, exercised intensively, and lost 18.0 kg (39.7 lb). On physical examination, the vital signs include blood pressure 100/60 mm Hg, heart rate 55/min, respiratory rate 12/min, and temperature 35.9°C (96.6°F). Her weight is 55.0 kg (121.3 lb), and her height is 166 cm (5 ft 5 in). Physical examination reveals the good development of muscles and decreased adiposity. A bone scan shows decreased calcium mineral deposits. Which statement about this patient’s condition is correct?
options: (A) This patient has insulin resistance (B) Decreased adiposity contributes to hypoestrogenemia in this patient (C) The patient is likely to have decreased blood estrogen concentration due to increased liver metabolism (D) The patient should be checked for hyperthyroidism because such extensive lipolysis is likely to result from thyroid hyperfunction
outputs:
The patient has not had menstrual periods for 6 months. She has a history of restricting her diet, exercising intensively, and losing 18.0 kg (39.7 lb) over the past year and a half. She is not sexually active. The patient's weight and height suggest that she has low body mass index (BMI). The patient's vital signs, particularly her low blood pressure (100/60 mm Hg) and low heart rate (55/min), suggest that she may have low estrogen levels. The patient's bone scan shows decreased calcium mineral deposits, which is consistent with low estrogen levels. The patient's history of decreased adiposity and low estrogen levels suggests that she may have hypoestrogenemia. The answer is (B).

Q: A 27-year-old woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus and Raynaud's phenomenon presents to the emergency department because of acute left knee pain. She has no history of knee trauma. She has been taking hydroxychloroquine, prednisone, and calcium channel blockers regularly. She has been smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 5 years. She has a history of recurrent abortions. Physical examination shows swelling and erythema of the left knee. The knee is warm to the touch, and there is a positive effusion sign. There is no evidence of infection. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Complete blood cell count shows a white blood cell count of 12,000/mm3, hemoglobin 11.4 g/dL, hematocrit 34%, and platelet count 180,000/mm3. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 30 mm/h, and C-reactive protein is 1.8 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 2+ protein and 1+ blood. The patient has a history of recurrent abortions. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Intravenous methylprednisolone (B) Intravenous immunoglobulin (C) Planned parenthood (D) Colchicine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus and Raynaud's phenomenon. She presents with acute left knee pain, swelling, and erythema. There is no evidence of infection. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Complete blood cell count shows a white blood cell count of 12,000/mm3, hemoglobin 11.4 g/dL, hematocrit 34%, and platelet count 180,000/mm3. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 30 mm/h, and C-reactive protein is 1.8 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 2+ protein and 1+ blood. The patient has a history of recurrent abortions. Given the patient's history of systemic lupus erythematosus and the presence of nephritis, the most likely diagnosis is lupus nephritis. The answer is (A).

Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg . Examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. Serum
Na+ 138 mEq/L

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?"

Q: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a 10-day history of fever and sore throat that acutely worsened over the past 2 days. Her sore throat is worse on the right side. She has difficulty swallowing and opening her mouth due to pain. She has also noticed a change in the quality of her voice over the last day. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg . Examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. Oropharyngeal examination shows erythematous tonsils and swelling of the right tonsillar pillar. The uvula is deviated to the left. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.0 g/dL
Hematocrit 39%
Leukocyte count 12,000/mm3
Platelet Count 200,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 138 mEq/L
Cl- 100 mEq/L
K+ 4.5 mEq/L
HCO3- 24 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 14.0 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?"
options: (A) Intravenous dexamethasone therapy (B) Incision and drainage with intravenous ampicillin-sulbactam therapy (C) Needle aspiration and oral clindamycin therapy (D) Intravenous ampicillin-sulbactam therapy
outputs:
The patient has a fever, sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a change in the quality of her voice. She also has cervical lymphadenopathy, erythematous tonsils, and swelling of the right tonsillar pillar. The uvula is deviated to the left. The patient has acute tonsillitis. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous ampicillin-sulbactam therapy. The answer is (D).

Q: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of sudden hearing loss and severe headache. She has no history of otologic or neurologic disorders. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.0 g/dL
Hematocrit 39%
Leukocyte count 7,000/mm3
Platelet Count 220,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 138 mEq/L
Cl- 100 mEq/L
K+ 4.5 mEq/L
HCO3- 24 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 14.0 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Intravenous dexamethasone therapy (B) CT scan of the head and mastoiditis (C) MRI of the internal auditory canals and brain stem (D) Intravenous ampicillin-sulbactam therapy
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has sudden hearing loss and severe headache. She has no history of otologic or neurologic disorders. The patient has a normal temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show normal hemoglobin, hematocrit, leukocyte count, platelet count, serum electrolytes, and renal function. The patient has no signs of infection or inflammation. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform a CT scan of the head and mastoiditis to evaluate for a possible mastoiditis. The answer is (B).

Q: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of worsening left knee pain. He states that he twisted his knee while playing soccer 2 days ago. He has been unable to bear weight on the knee since then. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows moderate swelling of the left knee. There is moderate tenderness to palpation over the patellar tendon. The patient has limited mobility of the left knee. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Radiographs of the knee (B) Arthrocentesis (C) Intravenous ceftriaxone and doxycycline (D) MRI of the knee
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has worsening left knee pain, which started after twisting his knee while playing soccer. He has moderate swelling of the left knee, moderate tenderness to palpation over the patellar tendon, and limited mobility of the left knee. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform radiographs of the knee to evaluate for a possible fracture or osteochondral injury. The answer is (A).

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 26-year-old nurse comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue. She has had a lot of stress at work and has been on sick leave for 2 weeks, but states that she would like to return to work. She has had several episodes of lower abdominal pain. She says, ""I know I have cancer."" She requests a diagnostic laparoscopy. She was diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease 6 months ago. Her only medication is omeprazole. The patient appears pale. Her temperature is 36.5° C (97.7° F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 90/65 mm Hg. On mental status examination she is tired and has a depressed mood. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae and dry mucous membranes. There are numerous crusts along the course of her left arm veins. A grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard along the right-upper sternal border. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. There is generalized weakness of the proximal muscles. Laboratory studies show:

Mean corpuscular volume 89 μm3
Reticulocyte count 13.3%
Serum
Sodium 139 mEq/L
Potassium 3.9 mEq/L
Calcium 8.5 mg/dL
Test of the stool for occult blood is negative. Abdominal ultrasonography show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?"
(A) Factitious disorder (B) Somatic symptom disorder (C) Conversion disorder (D) Acute small bowel hemorrhage
A: Let's think step by step.

Q: A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. She has had no previous similar episodes. Q: Five days after undergoing an emergency appendectomy under general inhalational anesthesia while on a trip to Haiti, a 43-year-old woman develops low-grade fever, vomiting, and abdominal pain. During the surgery, she received a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells. Three days after the surgery, she was stable enough to be transported back to the United States. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 138/76 mm Hg. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. Abdominal examination shows moderate tenderness over the liver. The liver is palpated 2 to 3 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin count 12.0 g/dL
Leukocyte count 10,400 mm3
Segmented neutrophils 55%
Bands 1%
Eosinophils 13%
Lymphocytes 28%
Monocytes 3%
Platelet count 160,000 mm3
Serum
Alkaline phosphatase 102 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase 760 U/L
Bilirubin
Total 3.8 mg/dL
Direct 3.1 mg/dL
Anti-HAV IgG positive
Anti-HAV IgM negative
Anti-HBs positive
HBsAg negative
Anti-HCV antibodies negative
Abdominal ultrasonography shows an enlarged liver. A biopsy of the liver shows massive centrilobular necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?"
options: (A) Adverse effect of anesthetic (B) Gram negative bacteria in the bloodstream (C) Acalculous inflammation of the gallbladder (D) Excessive lysis of red blood cells
outputs:
The patient has low-grade fever, vomiting, and abdominal pain after an emergency appendectomy under general inhalational anesthesia. She was stable enough to be transported back to the United States 3 days after the surgery. Her liver is palpated 2 to 3 cm below the right costal margin, and abdominal examination shows moderate tenderness over the liver. Laboratory studies show jaundice, elevated bilirubin, and abnormal liver function test results. The patient also has thrombocytopenia. The patient's history and physical examination are consistent with acute liver failure. The most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition is excessive lysis of red blood cells. The patient received a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells during the surgery. This could have caused excessive lysis of red blood cells, leading to hemolytic anemia and acute liver failure. The answer is (D).

Q: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe left eye pain that has been worsening over the past 2 hours. She has a history of hypertension and glaucoma. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmoscopy shows a relative afferent pupillary defect. The left eye shows a cloudy cornea and a shallow anterior chamber. The right eye is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical timolol
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe left eye pain that has been worsening over the past 2 hours. She has a history of hypertension and glaucoma. Ophthalmoscopy shows a relative afferent pupillary defect. The left eye shows a cloudy cornea and a shallow anterior chamber. The right eye is normal. These symptoms are consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform gonioscopy. Gonioscopy is the gold standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. The answer is (B).

Q: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, chills, and a productive cough that produces yellow-green sputum. She has a history of smoking and using illicit drugs. She appears ill. Vital signs are within normal limits. Chest examination shows rales and rhonchi. A chest x-ray shows a left lower lobe infiltrate. A sputum Gram stain shows numerous polymorphonuclear neutrophils and a few gram-positive cocci. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) (B) Aspiration pneumonia (C) Tuberculosis (D) Pneumocystis pneumonia
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 2-day history of fever, chills, and a productive cough that produces yellow-green sputum. She has a history of smoking and using illicit drugs. Chest examination shows rales and rhonchi. A chest x-ray shows a left lower lobe infiltrate. A sputum Gram stain shows numerous polymorphonuclear neutrophils and a few gram-positive cocci. These symptoms and findings are consistent with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The most likely diagnosis is community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The answer is (A).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fatigue and painless bruising over her arms and trunk. Leukocyte count 1100/mm3

LDH 80 U/L
Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?"
(A) Serum transferrin level (B) Bone marrow biopsy (C) Peripheral blood smear (D) Serum porphobilinogen level
A: Let's think step by step.

Q: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of sudden onset of severe, constant, substernal pain that radiates to the back and both arms. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform an electrocardiogram. The answer is (D).

Q: A 35-year-old man returns to the clinic to follow up for his chronic stomach pain. At the last visit a few months ago, he explained that he had been experiencing discomfort in his upper abdomen for awhile. He had never vomited up any blood and had not had any substantial weight loss. He did not take any medications, did not smoke, and had no family history of gastric cancer. At that time, the doctor empirically started him on a proton pump inhibitor (PPI). Today, despite the PPI, the patient says he is still experiencing discomfort. Hearing this, the doctor decides to order a urease breath test. What is the most likely cause of this patient's chronic stomach pain?
(A) Gastroesophgeal sphincter dysfunction (B) Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (C) Heliobacter pylori infection (D) Excessive gastrin
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 35-year-old man returns to the clinic to follow up for his chronic stomach pain. At the last visit a few months ago, he explained that he had been experiencing discomfort in his upper abdomen for awhile. He had never vomited up any blood and had not had any substantial weight loss. He did not take any medications, did not smoke, and had no family history of gastric cancer. At that time, the doctor empirically started him on a proton pump inhibitor (PPI). Today, despite the PPI, the patient says he is still experiencing discomfort. Hearing this, the doctor decides to order a urease breath test. What is the most likely cause of this patient's chronic stomach pain?
options: (A) Gastroesophgeal sphincter dysfunction (B) Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (C) Heliobacter pylori infection (D) Excessive gastrin
outputs:
The patient has chronic stomach pain and discomfort in his upper abdomen. He has not experienced any substantial weight loss and has never vomited up any blood. He does not take any medications, smoke, or have a family history of gastric cancer. The patient has been taking a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) empirically, but the pain persists. The patient's symptoms and history suggest a possible Helicobacter pylori infection. A urease breath test will help confirm this diagnosis. The answer is (C).

Q: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. She is afebrile and her blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A head CT shows a 1.5-cm left frontal intracerebral hemorrhage. The patient is immediately administered intravenous nimodipine. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous metoclopramide (B) Administer intravenous hydralazine (C) Administer intravenous labetalol (D) Administer intravenous furosemide
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. She is afebrile and her blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A head CT shows a 1.5-cm left frontal intracerebral hemorrhage. The patient is immediately administered intravenous nimodipine. Nimodipine is a calcium channel blocker that is used to treat cerebral vasospasm. The next step in management would be to administer a medication to lower the patient's blood pressure. Labetalol is a beta-blocker that is used to lower blood pressure and is commonly used in hypertensive emergencies. The answer is (C).

Q: A 35-year-old woman comes to the clinic for follow-up of her hypertension. She has been taking lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide for 6 months. Her blood pressure today is 126/80 mm Hg. She has been experiencing headaches and blurred vision for the past 2 weeks. She is currently taking no other medications. She has no history of migraines or other medical conditions. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
(A) Hypertensive crisis (B) Lisinopril-induced angioedema (C) Hydrochlorothiazide-induced hyperkalemia (D) Migraine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has been taking lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide for 6 months. Her blood pressure today is 126/80 mm Hg. She has been experiencing headaches and blurred vision for the past 2 weeks. She is currently taking no other medications. She has no history of migraines or other medical conditions. The patient's symptoms are consistent with lisinopril-induced angioedema. Angioedema is a known side effect of ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril. The patient's history of hypertension and use of lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide suggest that the angioedema is likely caused by the lisinopril. The answer is (B).

The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 32-year-old G1P1 patient presents to her obstetrician after having a positive pregnancy test at home. She reports that she and her husband had been trying to have a child for the past three months. She has no history of sexually transmitted disease, intravenous drug use, or blood transfusions, and she has never traveled outside of the United States. She was up-to-date on all immunizations before her pregnancy. Ultrasound is consistent with an 8-week gestational sac. The patient requests as few tests as possible, although she does not want to compromise the health of her fetus. Which of the following screening tests should be performed on all pregnant women?
(A) HIV, syphilis, and hepatitis B (B) HIV, syphilis, and N. gonorrhea (C) HIV, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C (D) HIV, syphilis, hepatitis B, N. gonorrhea, and C. trachomatis
A: Let's think step by step.

outputs:
