Q: A 55-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of an increasing sensation of fullness in the upper left side of his abdomen. He complains of increasing fatigue and dyspnea. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg. His conjunctivae are pale. The examination of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The splenic margin is palpable 8 cm (3.1 in) below the costal margin. No abnormal lymph nodes are found. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 90 μm3
Leukocyte count 3,000/mm3
Platelet count 85,000/mm3
Peripheral blood smear shows small lymphocytes with cell membrane projections. Bone marrow aspiration is unsuccessful. Cell immunophenotyping is positive for CD25. Which of the following is the most effective pharmacotherapy at this time?
(A) Cladribine (B) Fludarabine (C) Prednisone (D) Thalidomide
A: Let's think step by step.
question:
Q: A 55-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of an increasing sensation of fullness in the upper left side of his abdomen. He complains of increasing fatigue and dyspnea. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg. His conjunctivae are pale. The examination of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The splenic margin is palpable 8 cm (3.1 in) below the costal margin. No abnormal lymph nodes are found. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 90 μm3
Leukocyte count 3,000/mm3
Platelet count 85,000/mm3
Peripheral blood smear shows small lymphocytes with cell membrane projections. Bone marrow aspiration is unsuccessful. Cell immunophenotyping is positive for CD25. Which of the following is the most effective pharmacotherapy at this time?
options: (A) Cladribine (B) Fludarabine (C) Prednisone (D) Thalidomide
outputs:
The patient has a 2-month history of an increasing sensation of fullness in the upper left side of his abdomen, increasing fatigue, and dyspnea. He has pale conjunctivae and an enlarged spleen. The patient has a low hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), low leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and low platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His peripheral blood smear shows small lymphocytes with cell membrane projections. Bone marrow aspiration is unsuccessful. Cell immunophenotyping is positive for CD25. The most likely diagnosis is lymphoproliferative disorder (LPD). The most effective pharmacotherapy at this time is prednisone. The answer is (C).

Q: A 35-year-old woman presents with a 1-year history of progressive, painless swelling of her neck, shoulders, and upper arms. She has no history of weight loss, fever, or night sweats. She has no known allergies and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a large, firm, nontender swelling in the neck, shoulders, and upper arms. The swelling is symmetrical and has a rubbery consistency. There is no evidence of inflammation or infection. The rest of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13 g/dL
Leukocyte count 7,000/mm3
Platelet count 240,000/mm3
Serum chemistry studies are within normal limits. A chest x-ray shows no abnormalities. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the swelling shows numerous, small, uniform cells with a distinctive "salt and pepper" chromatin pattern. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Benign lymphadenopathy (B) Metastatic carcinoma (C) Multiple myeloma (D) Plasma cell dyscrasia
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 1-year history of progressive, painless swelling of her neck, shoulders, and upper arms. She has no history of weight loss, fever, or night sweats. The patient has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). The patient's fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the swelling shows numerous, small, uniform cells with a distinctive "salt and pepper" chromatin pattern. The most likely diagnosis is multiple myeloma. The answer is (C).

Q: A 45-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of sudden onset of severe, constant, substernal pain that radiates to the left shoulder. He has a history of hypertension and smoking. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tall, thin, obese man with a prominent abdomen. There is a markedly tender, firm, and immobile mass in the epigastrium. The rest of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12 g/dL
Leukocyte count 12,000/mm3
Platelet count 200,000/mm3
Serum chemistry studies are within normal limits. An electrocardiogram shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform an abdominal CT scan (B) Administer aspirin (C) Perform a cardiac stress test (D) Administer met

instring:

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department with confusion. His symptoms started a few days ago and have been gradually worsening. Initially, the patient had a fever and a cough which has progressed to abdominal pain, diarrhea, and confusion. His temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical exam is notable for localized crackles and decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung field. The patient is confused and is answering questions inappropriately. Laboratory studies are ordered as seen below.

Hemoglobin: 12 g/dL
Hematocrit: 36%
Leukocyte count: 16,500/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 190,000/mm^3

Serum:
Na+: 130 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 4.3 mEq/L
HCO3-: 25 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 99 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL

Which of the following is the best diagnostic test to guide current therapy in this patient?
(A) Chest radiography (B) Lung biopsy (C) Sputum culture (D) Urine antigen test
A: Let's think step by step.

outputs:

Q: A 37-year-old woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus and recent upper respiratory tract infection comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe headache, fever, and confusion. Her temperature is 103°F (39.4°C), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a confused patient with a non-focused gaze, and there is no evidence of meningism. There is no rash, and the remainder of the examination is unremarkable. The patient's blood cell count shows a WBC count of 18,000/mm3, with 80% polymorphonuclear neutrophils. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 30 mm/h. The patient's blood chemistry shows a sodium level of 135 mEq/L, potassium level of 4.0 mEq/L, chloride level of 100 mEq/L, bicarbonate level of 20 mEq/L, BUN level of 25 mg/dL, creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL, calcium level of 10.2 mg/dL, and magnesium level of 1.8 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 2+ protein and 5-10 WBC/hpf. A non-contrast head CT scan is performed and shows no evidence of intracranial abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

(A) Administer intravenous ceftriaxone and metronidazole (B) Perform lumbar puncture (C) Administer intravenous acyclovir (D) Obtain an MRI of the brain
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus and recent upper respiratory tract infection. She presents with fever, confusion, and headache. Her WBC count is 18,000/mm3, with 80% polymorphonuclear neutrophils. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 30 mm/h. Her blood chemistry is normal. Urinalysis shows 2+ protein and 5-10 WBC/hpf. A non-contrast head CT scan is performed and shows no evidence of intracranial abnormalities. Given the patient's symptoms and laboratory results, the most likely diagnosis is meningitis. The best diagnostic test to guide current therapy in this patient would be a lumbar puncture. The answer is (B).

Q: A 45-year-old man presents to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive pain and blurry vision in his right eye. He is struggling to open this eye because of the pain. His left eye is asymptomatic. He wears contact lenses. He has bronchial asthma treated with inhaled salbutamol. He works as a kindergarten teacher. The vital signs include: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 85/min, and blood pressure 135/75 mm Hg. The examination shows a visual acuity in the left eye of 20/25 and the ability to count fingers at 3 feet in the right eye. A photograph of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question: Q: A 45-year-old man presents to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive pain and blurry vision in his right eye. He is struggling to open this eye because of the pain. His left eye is asymptomatic. He wears contact lenses. He has bronchial asthma treated with inhaled salbutamol. He works as a kindergarten teacher. The vital signs include: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 85/min, and blood pressure 135/75 mm Hg. The examination shows a visual acuity in the left eye of 20/25 and the ability to count fingers at 3 feet in the right eye. A photograph of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: (A) Angle-closure glaucoma (B) Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (C) Herpes simplex keratitis (D) Pseudomonas keratitis
outputs:
The patient has progressive pain and blurry vision in his right eye. He has a history of bronchial asthma. The patient wears contact lenses. The patient's visual acuity in the left eye is 20/25, and the ability to count fingers at 3 feet in the right eye. The photograph of the right eye shows a corneal ulcer. The patient's symptoms, along with the photograph, are consistent with herpes simplex keratitis. The answer is (C).

Q: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of worsening dyspnea, wheezing, and cough. She has a history of hypertension and asthma. Her home medications include lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, and albuterol. She has no known drug allergies. She has been a nonsmoker for 10 years. She has been exposed to dust, pollen, and tobacco smoke. She is currently working as a secretary. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 138/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows the presence of bilateral expiratory wheezing and prolonged expiratory phase. The patient's peak flow rate is 400 L/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Admit the patient to the hospital (B) Administer a bronchodilator via a nebulizer (C) Perform spirometry (D) Order a high-resolution CT scan of the chest
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and asthma. The patient has a 2-day history of worsening dyspnea, wheezing, and cough. The patient's physical examination shows bilateral expiratory wheezing and a prolonged expiratory phase. The patient's peak flow rate is 400 L/min. The patient's symptoms and physical examination are consistent with an asthma exacerbation. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer a bronchodilator via a nebulizer. The answer is (B).

She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 50-year-old man presents to his physician with chronic cough, aching joints in his hips and lower back, and malaise over the past 2 months. He describes himself as being “generally healthy” before the cough began. Past medical history includes hypertension. The patient takes clopamide and a multivitamin daily. His parents are both well and living in a senior living facility. He does not smoke and only drinks alcohol occasionally. During a review of symptoms, the patient described a hiking trip in and around the desert near Phoenix, Arizona, 4 months ago. At the office, his temperature is 38.6°C (101.4°F), heart rate is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/82 mm Hg. A focused chest exam reveals mild fremetus and dullness with percussion on the right side. A chest X-ray shows a right-sided consolidation of the lower right lung, and a chest CT shows an irregular opacity measuring 3.8 cm x 3.0 cm in the sub-plural region of the right middle lobe, a small right-sided pleural effusion, and mild right-sided hilar adenopathy. A lung biopsy is performed to rule out cancer and reveals necrotic granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells and spherules with endospores in the surrounding tissues. The laboratory tests show the following results:
Hemoglobin 12.9 mg/dL
Leukocyte count 9,300/mm3
Platelet count 167,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 43 mm/hr
Periodic acid-Schiff and silver methenamine Positive
Acid-fast stain Negative
 Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Histoplasmosis (B) Mycetoma (C) Blastomycosis (D) Valley fever
A: Let's think step by step.

Q: A 44-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of fever, chills, and a productive cough with yellow sputum. She also has a 1-day history of worsening left knee pain. She has a history of hypertension and is taking lisinopril. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen, tender left knee with a large effusion. There is no focal neurological deficit. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous ceftriaxone and metronidazole (B) Perform arthrocentesis (C) Order a stat plain radiograph of the knee (D) Order a stat CT scan of the knee
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a fever, chills, and a productive cough with yellow sputum, which could be caused by pneumonia. She also has worsening left knee pain, which could be caused by a knee infection. The patient has a history of hypertension and is taking lisinopril. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen, tender left knee with a large effusion. There is no focal neurological deficit. The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform arthrocentesis to drain the effusion and to send the fluid for culture and sensitivity testing to determine if there is an infection. The answer is (B).

Q: A 22-year-old man with sickle cell disease is brought to the emergency room for acute onset facial asymmetry and severe pain. He was in school when his teacher noted a drooping of his left face. His temperature is 99.9°F (37.7°C), blood pressure is 122/89 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for facial asymmetry and 4/5 strength in the patient's upper and lower extremity. A CT scan of the head does not demonstrate an intracranial bleed. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
(A) Alteplase (B) Exchange transfusion (C) Heparin (D) Warfarin
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 22-year-old man with sickle cell disease is brought to the emergency room for acute onset facial asymmetry and severe pain. He was in school when his teacher noted a drooping of his left face. His temperature is 99.9°F (37.7°C), blood pressure is 122/89 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for facial asymmetry and 4/5 strength in the patient's upper and lower extremity. A CT scan of the head does not demonstrate an intracranial bleed. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
options: (A) Alteplase (B) Exchange transfusion (C) Heparin (D) Warfarin
outputs:
The patient has sickle cell disease and is experiencing acute onset facial asymmetry and severe pain. He has a drooping left face and weakness in his upper and lower extremities. These symptoms are consistent with a neurological event, such as a stroke. The patient's history of sickle cell disease increases the likelihood of a stroke caused by a sickling event. The patient's age and the presence of facial asymmetry also suggest a higher likelihood of a stroke. The absence of an intracranial bleed on CT scan supports this diagnosis. The most appropriate treatment for this patient would be Alteplase, a thrombolytic agent that can help dissolve the clot causing the stroke. The answer is (A).

Q: A 49-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypertension comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of worsening substernal pain. He also reports nausea, vomiting, and diaphoresis. He has no fever. He appears anxious. The patient's blood pressure is 190/110 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 110/min. There is a machinery murmur. A 12-lead ECG shows ST segment elevation in leads V3 through V6. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer sublingual nitroglycerin (B) Administer intravenous furosemide (C) Administer intravenous metoprolol (D) Perform an exercise stress test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of smoking and hypertension and is experiencing worsening substernal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diaphoresis. He has no fever. He appears anxious. The patient's blood pressure is 190/110 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 110/min. There is a machinery murmur. A 12-lead ECG shows ST segment elevation in leads V3 through V6. These symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a myocardial infarction (heart attack). The patient's history of smoking and hypertension increases the likelihood of cardiovascular disease. The presence of a machinery murmur and ST segment elevation on ECG also support this diagnosis. The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer sublingual nitroglycerin, which can help relieve the patient's chest pain and reduce the risk of further cardiac damage. The answer is (A).

Q: A 65-year-old woman with a history of osteoporosis and chronic back pain presents to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe low back pain, difficulty ambulating, and loss of bladder control. She has no history of previous back surgeries or significant medical comorbidities. On examination, her blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, heart rate is 90/min, and respiratory rate is 20/min. She appears uncomfortable. There is tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine, and her knees are mildly flexed. She has decreased anal tone and is unable to walk. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Order an urgent MRI of the lumbar spine (B) Administer intramuscular morphine (C) Perform a lumbar puncture (D) Refer the patient to physical therapy
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of osteoporosis and chronic back pain and is experiencing sudden onset of severe low back pain, difficulty ambulating, and loss of bladder control. These symptoms are consistent with a spinal fracture. The patient's history of osteoporosis increases the likelihood of a spinal fracture. The patient's age and the presence of back pain also support this diagnosis. The patient's decreased anal tone and inability to walk further support this diagnosis. The most appropriate next step in management would be to order an urgent MRI of the lumbar spine to confirm the diagnosis of a spinal fracture. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a productive cough for 5 days. Over the past month, she has had several episodes of watery stools. She is exclusively breastfed every 3–4 hours for 15–20 minutes. She was delivered vaginally at 38 weeks' gestation at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. The mother reports that her child is not gaining weight. The mother had no prenatal care. The infant is at the 5th percentile for height and weight. The infant has not received any immunizations. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 88/50 mm Hg. Oral examination shows white plaques covering the tongue and the palate. Rales are heard bilaterally on cardiopulmonary examination. Cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
(A) Karyotyping of infant's chromosomes (B) DNA test for CFTR mutation (C) Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (D) Polymerase chain reaction for viral genes
A: Let's think step by step.

Q: A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. She has had no previous similar episodes. She is currently at 16 weeks' gestation. She has been healthy otherwise. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient appears uncomfortable. She has no focal neurologic deficits. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis shows 1+ protein, 1+ blood, and a few RBCs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous magnesium sulfate (B) Perform a nonstress test (C) Administer intravenous furosemide (D) Perform an emergency cesarean delivery
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. She has had no previous similar episodes. She is currently at 16 weeks' gestation. She has been healthy otherwise. The patient appears uncomfortable. She has no focal neurologic deficits. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with preeclampsia. Preeclampsia is a condition that can occur during pregnancy and is characterized by high blood pressure and damage to organs such as the kidneys and liver. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform a nonstress test. The answer is (B).

Q: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of a painless, firm, nontender swelling of his right testis. He has no other symptoms. He has been healthy otherwise. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender, 2-cm mass in the right hemiscrotum. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. The patient has no focal neurologic deficits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous antibiotics (B) Perform a scrotal ultrasound (C) Perform a scrotal biopsy (D) Administer intravenous analgesia
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 2-week history of a painless, firm, nontender swelling of his right testis. He has no other symptoms. He has been healthy otherwise. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a testicular tumor. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform a scrotal ultrasound. The answer is (B).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 30-year-old primigravid woman at 22 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department by her husband for lethargy, nausea, and vomiting for 4 days. This morning she became drowsy. She returned from a business trip to Sudan 3 weeks ago. She denies eating any seafood while traveling. Medications include iron supplements and a multivitamin. Her immunizations are up-to-date and she has never received blood products. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg. She is oriented to person and place. Examination shows jaundice and mild asterixis. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 22-week gestation. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.2 g/dL
Prothrombin time 18 sec (INR=2.0)
Serum
Total bilirubin 4.4 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 398 U/L
AST 4,702 U/L
ALT 3,551 U/L
Lactate dehydrogenase 3,412 U/L
Anti-nuclear antibody negative
Anti-smooth muscle antibody negative
Anti-CMV antibody negative
Anti-EBV nuclear antigen antibody negative
An ELISA for HIV is negative. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?"
(A) HBsAg (B) Anti-HAV IgG (C) Anti-HCV IgG (D) Anti-HEV IgM
A: Let's think step by step.
question:
Q: A 30-year-old primigravid woman at 22 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department by her husband for lethargy, nausea, and vomiting for 4 days. This morning she became drowsy. She returned from a business trip to Sudan 3 weeks ago. She denies eating any seafood while traveling. Medications include iron supplements and a multivitamin. Her immunizations are up-to-date and she has never received blood products. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg. She is oriented to person and place. Examination shows jaundice and mild asterixis. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 22-week gestation. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.2 g/dL
Prothrombin time 18 sec (INR=2.0)
Serum
Total bilirubin 4.4 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 398 U/L
AST 4,702 U/L
ALT 3,551 U/L
Lactate dehydrogenase 3,412 U/L
Anti-nuclear antibody negative
Anti-smooth muscle antibody negative
Anti-CMV antibody negative
Anti-EBV nuclear antigen antibody negative
An ELISA for HIV is negative. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?"
options: (A) HBsAg (B) Anti-HAV IgG (C) Anti-HCV IgG (D) Anti-HEV IgM
outputs: The patient is a 30-year-old primigravid woman who is 22 weeks pregnant. She has been experiencing lethargy, nausea, and vomiting for 4 days and became drowsy this morning. She recently traveled to Sudan, which is an area where malaria is common. Malaria is a likely diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms and travel history. Malaria can cause jaundice and asterixis, which are both present in this patient. The patient's liver function tests are also consistent with malaria. The patient's Hb is 11.2 g/dL which is normal, and her prothrombin time is 18 sec (INR=2.0) which is also normal. The patient's bilirubin level is elevated, which could be due to hemolysis, a common complication of malaria. The patient's AST, ALT, and LDH levels are also elevated, which could be due to liver damage caused by malaria. The patient's negative anti-nuclear antibody, anti-smooth muscle antibody, anti-CMV antibody, and anti-EBV nuclear antigen antibody test results suggest that the patient does not have autoimmune hepatitis or viral hepatitis. The patient's negative HIV ELISA test result suggests that the patient does not have HIV-associated nephropathy. Given the patient's symptoms and travel history, malaria is the most likely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of multiple episodes of nonbilious emesis for 3 days. The vomitus consists of undigested food and he has also had dark brown emesis twice today. He has been having early satiety during this period. He has had progressive severe episodic epigastric pain and dyspepsia for the past week. The pain is partially relieved with food or over-the-counter antacids, but worsens at night and several hours after eating. He has also had a weight gain of 2 kg (4.4 lbs) during this period. His father underwent surgery for colon cancer 3 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 15 years. He drinks two to three beers daily. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 106/min and blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation in the left upper quadrant; there is a tympanitic mass in the epigastrium. A succussion splash is heard with a stethoscope when the patient is rocked back and forth at the hips. Bowel sounds are reduced. Rectal examination is unremarkable. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
Na+ 135 mEq/L
K+ 3.3 mEq/L
Cl- 97 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 46 mg/dL
Glucose 77 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL
Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient's vomiting?"
(A) Inflammation and edema (B) Abnormal gastric rotation (C) Neoplastic growth (D) Walled-off pancreatic fluid collection
A: Let's think step by step.

Q: A 44-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity (BMI 32 kg/m2) is seen for a routine follow-up. She has been compliant with her medications and has made appropriate lifestyle changes. Her blood pressure today is 138/88 mm Hg, and her lipids are within target. She has no complaints and appears well. However, her electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a prolonged QTc interval of 480 milliseconds. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Repeat the ECG in 1 week (B) Order an echocardiogram (C) Order a Holter monitor (D) Order a stress test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity. She has been compliant with her medications and has made appropriate lifestyle changes. Her blood pressure and lipids are within target. However, her electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a prolonged QTc interval of 480 milliseconds. A prolonged QTc interval can be a sign of a potentially life-threatening arrhythmia, such as torsades de pointes. This is a medical emergency, and the patient should be referred for a stress test as soon as possible. The answer is (D).

Q: A 35-year-old woman with a history of migraine headaches and depression presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of worsening headache, fever, and vomiting. She has not had any recent changes in her medications or personal history. She appears ill and has a temperature of 101.2°F (38.4°C). Her blood pressure is 126/80 mm Hg, and her pulse is 110/min. A review of her medications does not reveal any potential causes of her symptoms. A complete blood cell count and basic metabolic profile are within normal limits. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the opening pressure is elevated at 300 mm H2O. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is clear and colorless, with 100 white blood cells/mm3 and a protein level of 100 mg/dL. A Gram stain of the CSF shows numerous gram-positive cocci. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening shortness of breath for 6 hours. For the past 5 days, he has had intermittent stabbing pain in the middle of his chest that worsens with lying down or taking deep breaths. He has also had a runny nose and a dry cough for the past 2 weeks. He has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 34 years. His current medications include atorvastatin, enalapril, and hydrochlorothiazide. He appears pale and sweaty. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 25/min. Blood pressure is 107/72 mm Hg during expiration and 86/65 mm Hg during inspiration. Examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema below the knees. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
(A) Dilation of the atria and ventricles (B) Occlusion of a coronary artery (C) Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space (D) Fibrous thickening of the pericardium
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening shortness of breath for 6 hours. For the past 5 days, he has had intermittent stabbing pain in the middle of his chest that worsens with lying down or taking deep breaths. He has also had a runny nose and a dry cough for the past 2 weeks. He has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 34 years. His current medications include atorvastatin, enalapril, and hydrochlorothiazide. He appears pale and sweaty. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 25/min. Blood pressure is 107/72 mm Hg during expiration and 86/65 mm Hg during inspiration. Examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema below the knees. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
options: (A) Dilation of the atria and ventricles (B) Occlusion of a coronary artery (C) Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space (D) Fibrous thickening of the pericardium
outputs:
The patient has a history of smoking and has been experiencing worsening shortness of breath for 6 hours. He also has chest pain that worsens with lying down or taking deep breaths. He has a history of hypercholesterolemia and hypertension, which are risk factors for coronary artery disease. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a myocardial infarction. The most likely cause of this patient's findings is (B) Occlusion of a coronary artery.

Q: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of worsening fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats. She also reports a 1-month history of fever and chills, which has been persistent. She has no significant past medical history. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 20/min. Blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor, mild dehydration, and a grade 2/6 systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border. There is no lymphadenopathy or organomegaly. Urinalysis shows 2+ proteinuria and 1+ blood. A chest x-ray shows a left mid-peripheral lung lesion. A CT scan of the chest shows a 2-cm nodule in the left mid-peripheral lung. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the nodule shows malignant cells. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Sputum cytology (B) Bronchoscopy (C) CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis (D) Positron emission tomography (PET) scan
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of worsening fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats, as well as a 1-month history of fever and chills. She also has a grade 2/6 systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with lung cancer. The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform a bronchoscopy to obtain a tissue diagnosis. The answer is (B).

Q: A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden-onset left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath for 2 hours. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He has been compliant with his medications. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 24/min. Blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a pale, sweaty man with a regular rhythm, but no radiation of pain. There is a 2/6 systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border. There is no jugular venous distention or pitting edema. A 12-lead ECG shows ST elevation in leads V2 to V6. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Acute inferior wall myocardial infarction (B) Acute lateral wall myocardial infarction (C) Acute anterior wall myocardial infarction (D) Acute posterior wall myocardial infarction
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of smoking and hypertension. He has sudden-onset left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a 2/6 systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with an acute myocardial infarction. The most likely diagnosis is (A) Acute inferior wall myocardial infarction.

Q: A 70-year-old obese male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and cough of sudden onset. The patient states that his symptoms came on while he was sleeping. The patient has a past medical history of type II diabetes and is currently taking lisinopril, metformin, insulin, and fish oil. On physical exam, you note bipedal edema and jugular venous distention (JVD). An EKG and chest radiographs are obtained (Figures A and B). The patient is started on BIPAP and medical therapy and his symptoms improve rapidly. Lab values are as follows.

Serum:
Na+: 137 mEq/L
K+: 3.2 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
HCO3-: 31 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 120 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.9 mg/dL

Which of the following is the best explanation of this patient's current presentation?
(A) Furosemide (B) Hydrochlorothiazide (C) Renal tubular acidosis type II (D) Renal tubular acidosis type IV
A: Let's think step by step.
question:
Q: A 70-year-old obese male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and cough of sudden onset. The patient states that his symptoms came on while he was sleeping. The patient has a past medical history of type II diabetes and is currently taking lisinopril, metformin, insulin, and fish oil. On physical exam, you note bipedal edema and jugular venous distention (JVD). An EKG and chest radiographs are obtained (Figures A and B). The patient is started on BIPAP and medical therapy and his symptoms improve rapidly. Lab values are as follows.

Serum:
Na+: 137 mEq/L
K+: 3.2 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
HCO3-: 31 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 120 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.9 mg/dL

Which of the following is the best explanation of this patient's current presentation?
options: (A) Furosemide (B) Hydrochlorothiazide (C) Renal tubular acidosis type II (D) Renal tubular acidosis type IV
outputs:
The patient has shortness of breath and cough of sudden onset. He has a past medical history of type II diabetes and is currently taking lisinopril, metformin, insulin, and fish oil. On physical exam, you note bipedal edema and jugular venous distention (JVD). An EKG and chest radiographs are obtained (Figures A and B). The patient is started on BIPAP and medical therapy and his symptoms improve rapidly. The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal. The patient has hypokalemia (K+: 3.2 mEq/L, normal range 3.5-5.5 mEq/L). He also has metabolic acidosis (HCO3-: 31 mEq/L, normal range 22-29 mEq/L). The patient's BUN (20 mg/dL, normal range 6-20 mg/dL) and creatinine (1.2 mg/dL, normal range 0.5-1.1 mg/dL) levels are consistent with acute kidney injury. The patient's calcium level is also high (Ca2+: 10.9 mg/dL, normal range 8.9-10.1 mg/dL). The patient's presentation is consistent with acute kidney injury and hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of worsening fatigue, weight loss, and cold intolerance. She also has a 1-year history of intermittent constipation. She is currently taking no medications. Her temperature is 36.7°C (97.9°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a thin, pale woman with a body-mass index of 19 kg/m2. There is no evidence of thyromegaly or lymphadenopathy. The thyroid gland is nontender and without nodules. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory test results include a T4 of 40 ng/dL (N = 50–120), T3 of 25 ng/dL (N = 80–200), free T4 of 0.8 ng/dL (N = 0.8–1.8), and free T3 of 2.8 pg/mL (N = 2.3–4.2). The patient is started on levothyroxine, 25 μg orally once a day. One month after starting the medication, her T4 level is 70 ng/dL, T3 level is 85 ng/dL, free T4 level is 1.2 ng/dL, and free T3 level is 3.9 pg/mL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Discontinue levothyroxine and initiate liothyronine, 5 μg orally once a day (B) Discontinue levothyroxine and initiate liothyronine, 25 μg orally once a day (C) Increase the dose of levothyroxine to 50 μg orally once a day (D) Increase the dose of levothyroxine to 75 μg orally once a day
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 2-year history of worsening fatigue, weight loss, and cold intolerance. She also has a 1-year history of intermittent constipation. Her T4 and T3 levels are low. She is started on levothyroxine, 25 μg orally once a day. One month after starting the medication, her T4 level is 70 ng/dL, T3 level is 85 ng/dL, free T4 level is 1.2 ng/dL, and free T3 level is 3.9 pg/mL. The patient's T4 and T3 levels are still low despite taking levothyroxine for a month. The most appropriate next step in management is to increase the dose of levothyroxine. The answer is (C).
